<ce:section-title id="st010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">Hydrothermal reaction of the requisite metal nitrate, potassium terephthalate (K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>tere) and the dipyridylamide 3-pyridylisonicotinamide (3-pina) afforded a pair of crystalline coordination polymers whose dimensionality and topology depends critically on the metal coordination environment. The two new crystalline phases were structurally characterized via single-crystal X-ray diffraction. {[Zn(tere)(3-pina)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) manifests a 1-D zig-zag ribbon motif with monodentate 3-pina ligands. [Cd(tere)(3-pina)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) displays a self-penetrated 3-D network with 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>8 <ce:bold>mab</ce:bold> topology. Thermal and luminescent properties of these two new materials are also presented. Both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> show capability as sensors for nitroaromatic compounds via luminescence quenching, with better absorption for nitrobenzene than the more sterically bulky analyte <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-nitrophenol.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Hydrothermal reaction of the requisite metal nitrate, potassium terephthalate (K2tere) and the dipyridylamide 3-pyridylisonicotinamide (3-pina) afforded a pair of crystalline coordination polymers whose dimensionality and topology depends critically on the metal coordination environment. The two new crystalline phases were structurally characterized via single-crystal X-ray diffraction. {[Zn(tere)(3-pina)2]⋅2H2O} n  (1) manifests a 1-D zig-zag ribbon motif with monodentate 3-pina ligands. [Cd(tere)(3-pina)2] n  (2) displays a self-penetrated 3-D network with 446108 mab topology. Thermal and luminescent properties of these two new materials are also presented. Both 1 and 2 show capability as sensors for nitroaromatic compounds via luminescence quenching, with better absorption for nitrobenzene than the more sterically bulky analyte m-nitrophenol.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st020">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Over the past fifteen years, there has been an intense research spotlight on the exploratory synthesis and structure of crystalline coordination polymer solids. Interest remains strong due to potential of this genre of solid state materials in gas storage , molecular separations , ion exchange , heterogeneous catalysis , and as luminescent explosives trace detectors . The undeniable esthetic appeal of their underlying 1-D, 2-D, or 3-D topologies also provides an impetus for continued research efforts . Divalent zinc or cadmium ions have proven efficacious choices as the requisite cationic component, predicated on their closed shell <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> electronic configurations. Full <ce:italic>d</ce:italic> shell population results in forbidden visible light <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>d</ce:italic> transitions, imparting the transparent visible light spectral window required for fluorescent sensing  or second harmonic generation applications . Due to the lack of crystal field stabilization for divalent zinc and cadmium ions, coordination polymer structure direction is ascribed to the combined effects of ligand donor disposition, carboxylate binding mode and steric requirements, as opposed to a specific preferred metal coordination geometry.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past fifteen years, there has been an intense research spotlight on the exploratory synthesis and structure of crystalline coordination polymer solids. Interest remains strong due to potential of this genre of solid state materials in gas storage , molecular separations , ion exchange , heterogeneous catalysis , and as luminescent explosives trace detectors . The undeniable esthetic appeal of their underlying 1-D, 2-D, or 3-D topologies also provides an impetus for continued research efforts . Divalent zinc or cadmium ions have proven efficacious choices as the requisite cationic component, predicated on their closed shell d 10 electronic configurations. Full d shell population results in forbidden visible light d-d transitions, imparting the transparent visible light spectral window required for fluorescent sensing  or second harmonic generation applications . Due to the lack of crystal field stabilization for divalent zinc and cadmium ions, coordination polymer structure direction is ascribed to the combined effects of ligand donor disposition, carboxylate binding mode and steric requirements, as opposed to a specific preferred metal coordination geometry.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">A myriad number of different topologies have been reported for divalent zinc and cadmium coordination polymers with aromatic dicarboxylate and neutral dipyridyl linkers . Some of these display intriguing and rare self-penetrated networks, in which the shortest rings within the topology pass through other shortest rings. For example, [Cd(Hpht)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpy)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (pht<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>phthalate, bpy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-bipyridine) manifests a self-penetrated 6-connected 3-D network with 5<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>7 topology . Using the kinked and hydrogen bonding capable dipyridyl ligand 4,4′-dipyridylamine (dpa) afforded {[Cd(pht)(dpa)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>, which displays a unique chiral self-penetrated 4-connected 7<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:bold>yyz</ce:bold> topology based on interlocked helical subunits . In other cases, this combination of ligand types has allowed self-assembly of coordination polymers with enticing adsorptive properties. For example, the desolvated apohost of {[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tere)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpy)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O·DMF}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> can separate challenging mixtures of low molecular weight alkanes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A myriad number of different topologies have been reported for divalent zinc and cadmium coordination polymers with aromatic dicarboxylate and neutral dipyridyl linkers . Some of these display intriguing and rare self-penetrated networks, in which the shortest rings within the topology pass through other shortest rings. For example, [Cd(Hpht)2(bpy)] n  (pht=phthalate, bpy=4,4'-bipyridine) manifests a self-penetrated 6-connected 3-D network with 510647 topology . Using the kinked and hydrogen bonding capable dipyridyl ligand 4,4'-dipyridylamine (dpa) afforded {[Cd(pht)(dpa)(H2O)]⋅4H2O} n , which displays a unique chiral self-penetrated 4-connected 7482 yyz topology based on interlocked helical subunits . In other cases, this combination of ligand types has allowed self-assembly of coordination polymers with enticing adsorptive properties. For example, the desolvated apohost of {[Zn2(tere)2(bpy)]⋅H2O⋅DMF} n  can separate challenging mixtures of low molecular weight alkanes .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">In comparison to coordination polymers containing bpy or dpa ligands, there are fewer reports of related materials containing the hydrogen-bonding capable dipyridylamide ligand 3-pyridylnicotinamide (3-pina, 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>) or its isomeric dipyridylamide congeners . A 3-pina ligand can engage in both supramolecular hydrogen bonding donating and accepting pathways due to its central amide moiety, unlike the kinked dpa or rigid-rod bpy linkers. Different locked conformations are possible for 3-pina ligands when entrained in a coordination polymer network, including <ce:italic>syn</ce:italic> (with the 3-pyridyl ring nitrogen atom positioned on the same side of the molecule as the carbonyl oxygen atom) or <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> (with the 3-pyridyl ring nitrogen atom positioned on the opposite side of the molecule as the carbonyl oxygen atom, as depicted in ). The isostructural phases [M(tere)(3-pina)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Mn, Co) display identical (4,4) grid layer topologies, with the 3-pina ligands adopting a slightly twisted <ce:italic>syn</ce:italic> conformation in which their 3-pyridyl rings do not ligate . {[Cu(ip)(3-pina)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (ip<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>isophthalate) exhibits dimeric units pillared into a non-interpenetrated 3-D 6<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>8 <ce:bold>cds</ce:bold> network by tethering <ce:italic>syn</ce:italic> conformation 3-pina ligands, while ({[Cu(tbip)(3-pina)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (tbip<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-<ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-butylisophthalate) is a 1-D chain coordination polymer with a “butterfly” morphology brought about by syn conformation 3-pina ligands whose isonicotinamide 4-pyridyl rings do not ligate . It is thus clear that 3-pina can afford access to a wide variety of coordination polymer topologies in the presence of different aromatic dicarboxylate ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In comparison to coordination polymers containing bpy or dpa ligands, there are fewer reports of related materials containing the hydrogen-bonding capable dipyridylamide ligand 3-pyridylnicotinamide (3-pina,  ) or its isomeric dipyridylamide congeners . A 3-pina ligand can engage in both supramolecular hydrogen bonding donating and accepting pathways due to its central amide moiety, unlike the kinked dpa or rigid-rod bpy linkers. Different locked conformations are possible for 3-pina ligands when entrained in a coordination polymer network, including syn (with the 3-pyridyl ring nitrogen atom positioned on the same side of the molecule as the carbonyl oxygen atom) or anti (with the 3-pyridyl ring nitrogen atom positioned on the opposite side of the molecule as the carbonyl oxygen atom, as depicted in ). The isostructural phases [M(tere)(3-pina)2] n  (M=Mn, Co) display identical (4,4) grid layer topologies, with the 3-pina ligands adopting a slightly twisted syn conformation in which their 3-pyridyl rings do not ligate . {[Cu(ip)(3-pina)]⋅H2O} n  (ip=isophthalate) exhibits dimeric units pillared into a non-interpenetrated 3-D 658 cds network by tethering syn conformation 3-pina ligands, while ({[Cu(tbip)(3-pina)2(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (tbip=5-tert-butylisophthalate) is a 1-D chain coordination polymer with a "butterfly" morphology brought about by syn conformation 3-pina ligands whose isonicotinamide 4-pyridyl rings do not ligate . It is thus clear that 3-pina can afford access to a wide variety of coordination polymer topologies in the presence of different aromatic dicarboxylate ligands.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">We have therefore attempted to extend this underdeveloped 3-pina coordination chemistry into closed-shell configuration divalent metal systems. In this contribution we report the synthesis, single-crystal structural characterization, luminescent and nitroaromatics sensing properties, and thermal degradation behavior of two new dual-ligand coordination polymers, {[Zn(tere)(3-pina)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cd(tere)(3-pina)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). These phases show a very significant change in coordination polymer dimensionality and topology depending on the coordination environment present at the closed shell divalent metal ion.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We have therefore attempted to extend this underdeveloped 3-pina coordination chemistry into closed-shell configuration divalent metal systems. In this contribution we report the synthesis, single-crystal structural characterization, luminescent and nitroaromatics sensing properties, and thermal degradation behavior of two new dual-ligand coordination polymers, {[Zn(tere)(3-pina)2]⋅2H2O} n  (1) and [Cd(tere)(3-pina)2] n  (2). These phases show a very significant change in coordination polymer dimensionality and topology depending on the coordination environment present at the closed shell divalent metal ion.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st025">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st030">General considerations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Metal nitrates, terephthalic acid, and nitroaromatics were commercially obtained. Potassium terephthalate was obtained via the reaction of terephthalic acid with excess potassium hydroxide in ethanolic solution. The dipyridylamide ligand 3-pyridylisonicotinamide (3-pina) was prepared by a literature procedure . Water was deionized above 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Ω-cm in-house. Elemental analysis was carried out using a Perkin Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS/O Analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on powdered samples using a Perkin Elmer Spectrum One instrument. The luminescence spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained with a Hitachi F-4500 Fluorescence Spectrometer on solid crystalline samples anchored to quartz microscope slides with Rexon Corporation RX-22P ultraviolet-transparent epoxy adhesive. The same Hitachi F-4500 Fluorescence Spectrometer instrument was used for nitroaromatic absorption studies. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a TA Instruments Q50 thermal analyzer under flowing N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. Topological analysis of coordination polymer networks was carried out using TOPOS software .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General considerations

Metal nitrates, terephthalic acid, and nitroaromatics were commercially obtained. Potassium terephthalate was obtained via the reaction of terephthalic acid with excess potassium hydroxide in ethanolic solution. The dipyridylamide ligand 3-pyridylisonicotinamide (3-pina) was prepared by a literature procedure . Water was deionized above 3MΩ-cm in-house. Elemental analysis was carried out using a Perkin Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS/O Analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on powdered samples using a Perkin Elmer Spectrum One instrument. The luminescence spectra of 1 and 2 were obtained with a Hitachi F-4500 Fluorescence Spectrometer on solid crystalline samples anchored to quartz microscope slides with Rexon Corporation RX-22P ultraviolet-transparent epoxy adhesive. The same Hitachi F-4500 Fluorescence Spectrometer instrument was used for nitroaromatic absorption studies. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a TA Instruments Q50 thermal analyzer under flowing N2. Topological analysis of coordination polymer networks was carried out using TOPOS software .

The fluorescence spectrum was recorded with an excitation wavelength of 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. Stock solutions of nitrobenzene, <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-nitrophenol, and benzene (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M) in dimethyl sulfoxide were prepared. Aliquots of these stock solutions (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μL) were added sequentially to coordination polymer ethanol suspensions with sonication for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s after each addition. The emission spectra were measured before any analyte addition and after each aliquot of analyte solution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Nitroaromatic detection studies

A 5mg sample of coordination polymer 1 or 2 was suspended in 5mL ethanol in a volumetric flask, with immersion in an ultrasonic bath for 60s to ensure an even dispersion. The fluorescence spectrum was recorded with an excitation wavelength of 300nm. Stock solutions of nitrobenzene, m-nitrophenol, and benzene (1×10-4 M) in dimethyl sulfoxide were prepared. Aliquots of these stock solutions (10μL) were added sequentially to coordination polymer ethanol suspensions with sonication for 30s after each addition. The emission spectra were measured before any analyte addition and after each aliquot of analyte solution.

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Diffraction data for 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker-AXS SMART-CCD X-ray diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). The data were processed via saint  and subjected to Lorentz effect, polarization effect and absorption corrections using sadabs . The structures were solved using direct methods with shelxtl  using the olex2 software suite . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. Crystallographic details for 1 and 2 are given in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st055">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st060">Synthesis and infrared spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were prepared cleanly by hydrothermal reaction of the requisite metal nitrate, potassium terephthalate, and 3-pyridylisonicotinamide. Infrared spectra were consistent with the structural components as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Broad, weak bands at ∼3300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> signify the O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H bonds in the water molecules of crystallization and 3-pina N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H bonds. Weaker, high energy bands at ∼3000–3200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> are attributed to C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H bond stretching modes in all cases. Asymmetric and symmetric C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O stretching modes of the tere ligands are marked by strong bands at 1556<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 1359<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and 1537<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 1366<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). Sharp, medium intensity bands in the range of ∼1600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> to ∼1200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> are attributed to the stretching modes of the pyridyl rings of the 3-pina ligands . Features corresponding to pyridyl and aryl ring puckering are observed in the region between 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Sharp, moderate intensity bands at 1687<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 1678<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> denote the C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O stretching bands within the amide moieties of the 3-pina ligands for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and infrared spectroscopy

Compounds 1 and 2 were prepared cleanly by hydrothermal reaction of the requisite metal nitrate, potassium terephthalate, and 3-pyridylisonicotinamide. Infrared spectra were consistent with the structural components as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Broad, weak bands at ~3300cm-1 signify the OH bonds in the water molecules of crystallization and 3-pina NH bonds. Weaker, high energy bands at ~3000-3200cm-1 are attributed to CH bond stretching modes in all cases. Asymmetric and symmetric CO stretching modes of the tere ligands are marked by strong bands at 1556cm-1 and 1359cm-1 (1) and 1537cm-1 and 1366cm-1 (2). Sharp, medium intensity bands in the range of ~1600cm-1 to ~1200cm-1 are attributed to the stretching modes of the pyridyl rings of the 3-pina ligands . Features corresponding to pyridyl and aryl ring puckering are observed in the region between 800cm-1 and 600cm-1. Sharp, moderate intensity bands at 1687cm-1 and 1678cm-1 denote the CO stretching bands within the amide moieties of the 3-pina ligands for 1 and 2, respectively.

Operation of the rotation axis generates a {ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} tetrahedral coordination environment, with the nitrogen donors belonging to the 3-pyridyl rings of two different 3-pina ligands. The isonicotinamide 4-pyridyl nitrogen atoms do not ligate to zinc. The oxygen donors belong to monodentate carboxylate groups of two different tere ligands. Bond lengths and angles within the tetrahedral coordination environment are listed in

elements.clean_text:
Structural description of {[Zn(tere)(3-pina)2]⋅2H2O} n  (1)

The asymmetric unit of compound 1 contains a divalent zinc atom on a crystallographic 2-fold rotation axis, a complete 3-pina ligand, and half of a tere ligand whose centroid is sited on a crystallographic inversion center, and a water molecule of crystallization. Operation of the rotation axis generates a {ZnO2N2} tetrahedral coordination environment, with the nitrogen donors belonging to the 3-pyridyl rings of two different 3-pina ligands. The isonicotinamide 4-pyridyl nitrogen atoms do not ligate to zinc. The oxygen donors belong to monodentate carboxylate groups of two different tere ligands. Bond lengths and angles within the tetrahedral coordination environment are listed in  , with a thermal ellipsoid plot depicted in  a.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Bis(monodentate) tere ligands conjoin divalent zinc atoms into neutral zig-zag [Zn(tere)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chain motifs with a Zn⋯Zn distance of 11.098<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. These are decorated by the monodentate <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> conformation 3-pina ligands to afford neutral [Zn(tere)(3-pina)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> ribbons (b). Viewing the ribbon motif down [1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1] gives a perspective of an “X” shape (c). Adjacent [Zn(tere)(3-pina)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> ribbons aggregate () by hydrogen bonding patterns () involving isolated water molecules of crystallization located in small solvent-accessible pockets comprising 2.0% of the unit cell volume according to PLATON . The water molecules of crystallization accept hydrogen bonds from N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H groups within the amide functional groups of the 3-pina ligands, and donate hydrogen bonds to unligated isonicotinamide pyridyl nitrogen atoms in 3-pina ligands and to unligated tere carboxylate oxygen atoms in neighboring ribbons. Non-classical C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H⋯O hydrogen bonding interactions between tere aromatic carbon atoms, and the carbonyl group within 3-pina ligands in neighboring ribbons, serve an ancillary role in the inter-ribbon aggregation.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Bis(monodentate) tere ligands conjoin divalent zinc atoms into neutral zig-zag [Zn(tere)] n  chain motifs with a Zn⋯Zn distance of 11.098Å. These are decorated by the monodentate anti conformation 3-pina ligands to afford neutral [Zn(tere)(3-pina)2] n  ribbons (b). Viewing the ribbon motif down [101] gives a perspective of an "X" shape (c). Adjacent [Zn(tere)(3-pina)2] n  ribbons aggregate () by hydrogen bonding patterns () involving isolated water molecules of crystallization located in small solvent-accessible pockets comprising 2.0% of the unit cell volume according to PLATON . The water molecules of crystallization accept hydrogen bonds from NH groups within the amide functional groups of the 3-pina ligands, and donate hydrogen bonds to unligated isonicotinamide pyridyl nitrogen atoms in 3-pina ligands and to unligated tere carboxylate oxygen atoms in neighboring ribbons. Non-classical CH⋯O hydrogen bonding interactions between tere aromatic carbon atoms, and the carbonyl group within 3-pina ligands in neighboring ribbons, serve an ancillary role in the inter-ribbon aggregation.

Operation of the crystallographic inversion center generates a {CdO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} distorted octahedral coordination environment, with trans nitrogen donor atoms belonging to the 3-pyridyl rings of two different 3-pina ligands, and another set of trans nitrogen donor atoms belonging to the isonicotinamide pyridyl rings of two additional 3-pina ligands. The oxygen atom donors are provided by two tere ligands. Bond lengths and angles within the octahedral coordination environment at cadmium are listed in

elements.clean_text:
Structural description of [Cd(tere)(3-pina)2] n  (2)

The asymmetric unit of compound 2 contains a divalent cadmium atom on a crystallographic inversion center, half of a tere ligand whose centroid rests on another inversion center, and a complete 3-pina ligand. Operation of the crystallographic inversion center generates a {CdO2N4} distorted octahedral coordination environment, with trans nitrogen donor atoms belonging to the 3-pyridyl rings of two different 3-pina ligands, and another set of trans nitrogen donor atoms belonging to the isonicotinamide pyridyl rings of two additional 3-pina ligands. The oxygen atom donors are provided by two tere ligands. Bond lengths and angles within the octahedral coordination environment at cadmium are listed in  , and a thermal ellipsoid plot is drawn in  a.

<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (4,4) coordination polymer grid motifs (b) by tethering <ce:italic>syn</ce:italic> conformation 3-pina ligands, that span a Cd⋯Cd distance of 12.432<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The grid apertures are rather pinched, with through-space Cd⋯Cd distances of 7.302 and 23.768<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; the Cd⋯Cd⋯Cd angles around the perimeter of all the grid windows measure 34.1° and 145.9°. The cationic [Cd(3-pina)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> layers in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are situated parallel to the (1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1) crystal planes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Cadmium atoms are connected into cationic [Cd(3-pina)2] n  (4,4) coordination polymer grid motifs (b) by tethering syn conformation 3-pina ligands, that span a Cd⋯Cd distance of 12.432Å. The grid apertures are rather pinched, with through-space Cd⋯Cd distances of 7.302 and 23.768Å; the Cd⋯Cd⋯Cd angles around the perimeter of all the grid windows measure 34.1° and 145.9°. The cationic [Cd(3-pina)2] n  layers in 2 are situated parallel to the (101) crystal planes.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Parallel [Cd(3-pina)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> layers stack along (1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0), with a closest Cd⋯Cd contact distance of 8.984<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å that matches the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> lattice parameter. However, this distance is too small to be pillared by any charge-balancing tere ligands. Instead the bis(monodentate) tere ligands connect cadmium atoms in neighboring layers in a crossed fashion in order to span a Cd⋯Cd distance of 11.577<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in the resulting [Cd(tere)(3-pina)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> 3-D coordination polymer network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). Straight pillaring would result in a standard 4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> primitive-cubic like network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>a), but the crossed pillaring necessitated by the long span of the tere ligands in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> affords a 6-connected 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>8 <ce:bold>mab</ce:bold> self-penetrated network (b). There have been some previous reports of this self-penetrated <ce:bold>mab</ce:bold> topology . However, most of these prior phases feature metal dicarboxylate layers with paddlewheel dinuclear units pillared by dipyridyl ligands, for example in [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(glutarate)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpmp)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (bpmp<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine) . Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> thus represents a rare example of a metal-dipyridyl layered coordination polymer pillared into a self-penetrated network by the dicarboxylate ligands. There are no solvent-accessible voids within the self-penetrated network of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Parallel [Cd(3-pina)2] n  layers stack along (100), with a closest Cd⋯Cd contact distance of 8.984Å that matches the a lattice parameter. However, this distance is too small to be pillared by any charge-balancing tere ligands. Instead the bis(monodentate) tere ligands connect cadmium atoms in neighboring layers in a crossed fashion in order to span a Cd⋯Cd distance of 11.577Å in the resulting [Cd(tere)(3-pina)2] n  3-D coordination polymer network ( ). Straight pillaring would result in a standard 41263 pcu primitive-cubic like network ( a), but the crossed pillaring necessitated by the long span of the tere ligands in 2 affords a 6-connected 446108 mab self-penetrated network (b). There have been some previous reports of this self-penetrated mab topology . However, most of these prior phases feature metal dicarboxylate layers with paddlewheel dinuclear units pillared by dipyridyl ligands, for example in [Cu2(glutarate)2(bpmp)] n  (bpmp=bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine) . Compound 2 thus represents a rare example of a metal-dipyridyl layered coordination polymer pillared into a self-penetrated network by the dicarboxylate ligands. There are no solvent-accessible voids within the self-penetrated network of 2.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st075">Thermal properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> underwent dehydration between 85 and 110<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, with a mass loss of 5.8% corresponding well with the predicted value for two molar equivalents of water (5.4%). Combustion of the organic ligands occurred above 240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The mass of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> remained stable until 330<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, whereupon ligand ejection occurred. TGA traces for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are shown in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal properties

Compound 1 underwent dehydration between 85 and 110°C, with a mass loss of 5.8% corresponding well with the predicted value for two molar equivalents of water (5.4%). Combustion of the organic ligands occurred above 240°C. The mass of compound 2 remained stable until 330°C, whereupon ligand ejection occurred. TGA traces for 1 and 2 are shown in .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st080">Luminescence spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Solid samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were irradiated with ultraviolet light to examine their photoluminescent behavior. The excitation spectra for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were recorded by monitoring emission at 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, revealing maximum excitation wavelengths of 337<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 320<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively. Upon excitation at this wavelength, modest blue-violet visible light emission was observed in both cases. The emission maxima for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were 467<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 441<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). When the pure 3-pina ligand was irradiated at 265<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, a blue emission with broad spectral profile centered at 465<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm was observed (). The fluorescent properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are ascribed to π–π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> molecular orbital transitions within the aromatic ring systems of the 3-pina and tere ligands .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence spectra

Solid samples of 1 and 2 were irradiated with ultraviolet light to examine their photoluminescent behavior. The excitation spectra for 1 and 2 were recorded by monitoring emission at 400nm, revealing maximum excitation wavelengths of 337nm and 320nm, respectively. Upon excitation at this wavelength, modest blue-violet visible light emission was observed in both cases. The emission maxima for 1 and 2 were 467nm and 441nm, respectively ( ). When the pure 3-pina ligand was irradiated at 265nm, a blue emission with broad spectral profile centered at 465nm was observed (). The fluorescent properties of 1 and 2 are ascribed to π-π∗ molecular orbital transitions within the aromatic ring systems of the 3-pina and tere ligands .

elements.clean_text:
Nitroaromatic sensing

Both compounds 1 and 2 show capability for detection of nitrobenzene (  , respectively) and m-nitrophenol (  , respectively) in ethanol suspension. Addition of small aliquots of nitroaromatic compounds dissolved in DMSO (1×10-4 M) resulted in diminution of the coordination polymer luminescence intensity upon excitation with ultraviolet light (λ ex =300nm). This loss of emission signal is attributed to charge transfer from the excited states of the ligand molecular orbitals within the coordination polymer, to those of the adsorbed electron-withdrawing nitroaromatic substrate . As control experiments, aliquots of a benzene solutions in DMSO (1×10-4 M) were added to ethanol suspensions of both 1 and 2. Only a very small decrease in luminescence intensity was observed in either case (, respectively). Thus, it is averred that coordination polymers 1 and 2 are functional detectors for nitroaromatic compounds. Both compounds 1 and 2 show enhanced absorption of nitrobenzene compared to the more sterically bulky m-nitrophenol. For nitrobenzene, the intensity factor (I o - I)/I o (I o =maximum intensity in the absence of analyte) reaches a level about 13% of the initial I o value for both 1 and 2 after 200μL of the stock analyte solution was added (). For m-nitrophenol, the comparable intensity factor reaches 0.57 and 0.43 for 1 and 2, respectively. The 3-D structure of compound 2 thus appears to be able to absorb more m-nitrophenol than the 1-D structure of compound 1 ().

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st090">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">A pair of closed-shell divalent metal terephthalate coordination polymers with ancillary 3-pina ligands has been prepared and structurally characterized. Although both the zinc and cadmium derivatives have the same ratio of ligands and a similar bis(monodentate)terephthalate binding mode, their structural topologies are radically different. The smaller ionic radius of zinc affords a 4-coordinate tetrahedral arrangement of donors. As the pendant 4-pyridyl donor atoms of the 3-pina ligands cannot bind, a zig-zag chain motif is observed in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Expansion of the coordination sphere to octahedral, due to the larger ionic radius of cadmium, results in the ability to ligate all of the 3-pina donor atoms, which instills the generation of the 3-D net seen in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. As the interlayer spacing is too small for direct terephthalate bridging, an uncommon 6-connected self-penetrated network is observed in the cadmium derivative. Ancillary structure-directing effects provided by different 3-pina conformations (<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:italic>syn</ce:italic> in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and amide group hydrogen bonding patterns act in a synergistic fashion with the predominating coordination environment effects. The self-penetration of the coordination polymer network in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> resulted in added thermal stability. Both materials show promise as sensors for the detection of nitroaromatic compounds in solution, with a preference for less sterically bulky analytes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A pair of closed-shell divalent metal terephthalate coordination polymers with ancillary 3-pina ligands has been prepared and structurally characterized. Although both the zinc and cadmium derivatives have the same ratio of ligands and a similar bis(monodentate)terephthalate binding mode, their structural topologies are radically different. The smaller ionic radius of zinc affords a 4-coordinate tetrahedral arrangement of donors. As the pendant 4-pyridyl donor atoms of the 3-pina ligands cannot bind, a zig-zag chain motif is observed in 1. Expansion of the coordination sphere to octahedral, due to the larger ionic radius of cadmium, results in the ability to ligate all of the 3-pina donor atoms, which instills the generation of the 3-D net seen in 2. As the interlayer spacing is too small for direct terephthalate bridging, an uncommon 6-connected self-penetrated network is observed in the cadmium derivative. Ancillary structure-directing effects provided by different 3-pina conformations (anti in 1, syn in 2) and amide group hydrogen bonding patterns act in a synergistic fashion with the predominating coordination environment effects. The self-penetration of the coordination polymer network in 2 resulted in added thermal stability. Both materials show promise as sensors for the detection of nitroaromatic compounds in solution, with a preference for less sterically bulky analytes.

Preparation of {[Zn(tere)(3-pina)2]⋅2H2O} n  (1)

Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (113mg, 0.38mmol), 3-pina (74mg, 0.37mmol), and potassium terephthalate (89mg, 0.37mmol) were mixed with 10mL of distilled H2O in a 23mL Teflon-lined acid digestion bomb. The bomb was sealed and heated in an oven at 120°C for 50h, and then was cooled slowly to 25°C. Colorless crystals of 1 (95mg, 77% yield based on 3-pina) were isolated after washing with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. C30H26N6O8Zn 1 calc. C, 54.27; H, 3.95; N, 12.66; found C, 54.13; H, 3.91; N, 12.43%. IR (    ν   ̃    )=3064 (w), 1687 (m), 1595 (s), 1556 (s), 1487 (m), 1422 (m), 1393 (m), 1359 (s), 1333 (s), 1303 (s), 1250 (m), 1200 (m), 1131 (w), 1067 (m), 1023 (w), 896 (w), 843 (m), 826 (m), 754 (s), 689 (s), 655 (m) cm-1.

Preparation of [Cd(tere)(3-pina)2] n  (2)

Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (114mg, 0.37mmol), 3-pina (74mg, 0.37mmol), and potassium terephthalate (89mg, 0.37mmol) were mixed with 10mL of distilled H2O in a 23mL Teflon-lined acid digestion bomb. The bomb was sealed and heated in an oven at 120°C for 144h, and then was cooled slowly to 25°C. Colorless crystals of 2 (112mg, 89% yield based on 3-pina) were isolated after washing with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. C30H22CdN6O6 calc. C, 53.39; H, 3.29; N, 12.45; found C, 52.87; H, 3.11; N, 11.98%. IR (    ν   ̃    )=3591 (w), 3056 (w), 2911 (w), 1677 (m), 1560 (s), 1537 (s), 1486 (w), 1424 (m), 1366 (s), 1330 (m), 1303 (s), 1008 (m), 895 (m), 840 (w), 812 (s), 746 (s), 693 (s) cm-1.

Nitroaromatic detection studies

A 5mg sample of coordination polymer 1 or 2 was suspended in 5mL ethanol in a volumetric flask, with immersion in an ultrasonic bath for 60s to ensure an even dispersion. The fluorescence spectrum was recorded with an excitation wavelength of 300nm. Stock solutions of nitrobenzene, m-nitrophenol, and benzene (1×10-4 M) in dimethyl sulfoxide were prepared. Aliquots of these stock solutions (10μL) were added sequentially to coordination polymer ethanol suspensions with sonication for 30s after each addition. The emission spectra were measured before any analyte addition and after each aliquot of analyte solution.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Cadmium atoms are connected into cationic [Cd(3-pina)2] n  (4,4) coordination polymer grid motifs (b) by tethering syn conformation 3-pina ligands, that span a Cd⋯Cd distance of 12.432Å. The grid apertures are rather pinched, with through-space Cd⋯Cd distances of 7.302 and 23.768Å; the Cd⋯Cd⋯Cd angles around the perimeter of all the grid windows measure 34.1° and 145.9°. The cationic [Cd(3-pina)2] n  layers in 2 are situated parallel to the (101) crystal planes.

Thermal properties

Compound 1 underwent dehydration between 85 and 110°C, with a mass loss of 5.8% corresponding well with the predicted value for two molar equivalents of water (5.4%). Combustion of the organic ligands occurred above 240°C. The mass of compound 2 remained stable until 330°C, whereupon ligand ejection occurred. TGA traces for 1 and 2 are shown in .

Luminescence spectra

Solid samples of 1 and 2 were irradiated with ultraviolet light to examine their photoluminescent behavior. The excitation spectra for 1 and 2 were recorded by monitoring emission at 400nm, revealing maximum excitation wavelengths of 337nm and 320nm, respectively. Upon excitation at this wavelength, modest blue-violet visible light emission was observed in both cases. The emission maxima for 1 and 2 were 467nm and 441nm, respectively ( ). When the pure 3-pina ligand was irradiated at 265nm, a blue emission with broad spectral profile centered at 465nm was observed (). The fluorescent properties of 1 and 2 are ascribed to π-π∗ molecular orbital transitions within the aromatic ring systems of the 3-pina and tere ligands .

Nitroaromatic sensing

Both compounds 1 and 2 show capability for detection of nitrobenzene (  , respectively) and m-nitrophenol (  , respectively) in ethanol suspension. Addition of small aliquots of nitroaromatic compounds dissolved in DMSO (1×10-4 M) resulted in diminution of the coordination polymer luminescence intensity upon excitation with ultraviolet light (λ ex =300nm). This loss of emission signal is attributed to charge transfer from the excited states of the ligand molecular orbitals within the coordination polymer, to those of the adsorbed electron-withdrawing nitroaromatic substrate . As control experiments, aliquots of a benzene solutions in DMSO (1×10-4 M) were added to ethanol suspensions of both 1 and 2. Only a very small decrease in luminescence intensity was observed in either case (, respectively). Thus, it is averred that coordination polymers 1 and 2 are functional detectors for nitroaromatic compounds. Both compounds 1 and 2 show enhanced absorption of nitrobenzene compared to the more sterically bulky m-nitrophenol. For nitrobenzene, the intensity factor (I o - I)/I o (I o =maximum intensity in the absence of analyte) reaches a level about 13% of the initial I o value for both 1 and 2 after 200μL of the stock analyte solution was added (). For m-nitrophenol, the comparable intensity factor reaches 0.57 and 0.43 for 1 and 2, respectively. The 3-D structure of compound 2 thus appears to be able to absorb more m-nitrophenol than the 1-D structure of compound 1 ().
